segment.source: Behind your UI are your business and data layers.
segment.target: Behind your UI are your business and data layers.

segment.source: Porting Windows Phone Silverlight business and data layers to UWP
segment.target: Porting Windows Phone Silverlight business and data layers to UWP

segment.source: Porting Windows Phone Silverlight business and data layers to UWP
segment.target: Porting Windows Phone Silverlight business and data layers to UWP

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: The previous topic was Porting for I/O, device, and app model.
segment.target: The previous topic was Porting for I/O, device, and app model.

segment.source: Behind your UI are your business and data layers.
segment.target: Behind your UI are your business and data layers.

segment.source: The code in these layers calls operating system and .NET Framework APIs (for example, background processing, location, the camera, the file system, network, and other data access).
segment.target: The code in these layers calls operating system and .NET Framework APIs (for example, background processing, location, the camera, the file system, network, and other data access).

segment.source: The vast majority of those are available to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app, so you can expect to be able to port much of this code without change.
segment.target: The vast majority of those are available to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app, so you can expect to be able to port much of this code without change.

segment.source: Asynchronous methods
segment.target: Asynchronous methods

segment.source: One of the priorities of the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) is to enable you to build apps that are truly, and consistently, responsive.
segment.target: One of the priorities of the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) is to enable you to build apps that are truly, and consistently, responsive.

segment.source: Animations are always smooth, and touch interactions such as panning and swiping are instantaneous and free of lag, making it feel like the UI is glued to your finger.
segment.target: Animations are always smooth, and touch interactions such as panning and swiping are instantaneous and free of lag, making it feel like the UI is glued to your finger.

segment.source: To achieve this, any UWP API that can't guarantee to complete within 50ms has been made asynchronous and its name suffixed with Async.
segment.target: To achieve this, any UWP API that can't guarantee to complete within 50ms has been made asynchronous and its name suffixed with Async.

segment.source: Your UI thread will return immediately from calling an Async method, and the work will take place on another thread.
segment.target: Your UI thread will return immediately from calling an Async method, and the work will take place on another thread.

segment.source: Consuming an Async method is made very easy, syntactically, using the C# await operator, JavaScript promise objects, and C++ continuations.
segment.target: Consuming an Async method is made very easy, syntactically, using the C# await operator, JavaScript promise objects, and C++ continuations.

segment.source: For more info, see Asynchronous programming.
segment.target: For more info, see Asynchronous programming.

segment.source: Background processing
segment.target: Background processing

segment.source: A Windows Phone Silverlight app can use a managed ScheduledTaskAgent object to perform a task while the app is not in the foreground.
segment.target: A Windows Phone Silverlight app can use a managed ScheduledTaskAgent object to perform a task while the app is not in the foreground.

segment.source: A UWP app uses the BackgroundTaskBuilder class to create and register a background task in a similar way.
segment.target: A UWP app uses the BackgroundTaskBuilder class to create and register a background task in a similar way.

segment.source: You define a class that implements the work of your background task.
segment.target: You define a class that implements the work of your background task.

segment.source: The system runs your background task periodically, calling the Run method of your class to execute the work.
segment.target: The system runs your background task periodically, calling the Run method of your class to execute the work.

segment.source: In a UWP app, remember to set the Background Tasks declaration in the app package manifest.
segment.target: In a UWP app, remember to set the Background Tasks declaration in the app package manifest.

segment.source: For more info, see Support your app with background tasks.
segment.target: For more info, see Support your app with background tasks.

segment.source: To transfer large data files in the background, a Windows Phone Silverlight app uses the BackgroundTransferService class.
segment.target: To transfer large data files in the background, a Windows Phone Silverlight app uses the BackgroundTransferService class.

segment.source: A UWP app uses APIs in the Windows.Networking.BackgroundTransfer namespace to do this.
segment.target: A UWP app uses APIs in the Windows.Networking.BackgroundTransfer namespace to do this.

segment.source: The features use a similar pattern to initiate transfers, but the new API has improved capabilities and performance.
segment.target: The features use a similar pattern to initiate transfers, but the new API has improved capabilities and performance.

segment.source: For more info, see Transferring data in the background.
segment.target: For more info, see Transferring data in the background.

segment.source: A Windows Phone Silverlight app uses the managed classes in the Microsoft.Phone.BackgroundAudio namespace to play audio while the app is not in the foreground.
segment.target: A Windows Phone Silverlight app uses the managed classes in the Microsoft.Phone.BackgroundAudio namespace to play audio while the app is not in the foreground.

segment.source: The UWP uses the Windows Phone Store app model, see Background Audio and the Background audio sample.
segment.target: The UWP uses the Windows Phone Store app model, see Background Audio and the Background audio sample.

segment.source: Cloud services, networking, and databases
segment.target: Cloud services, networking, and databases

segment.source: Hosting data and app services in the cloud is possible using Azure.
segment.target: Hosting data and app services in the cloud is possible using Azure.

segment.source: See Getting Started with Mobile Services.
segment.target: See Getting Started with Mobile Services.

segment.source: For solutions that require both online and offline data see: Using offline data sync in Mobile Services.
segment.target: For solutions that require both online and offline data see: Using offline data sync in Mobile Services.

segment.source: The UWP has partial support for the System.Net.HttpWebRequest class, but the System.Net.WebClient class is not supported.
segment.target: The UWP has partial support for the System.Net.HttpWebRequest class, but the System.Net.WebClient class is not supported.

segment.source: The recommended, forward-looking alternative is the Windows.Web.Http.HttpClient class (or System.Net.Http.HttpClient if you need your code to be portable to other platforms that support .NET).
segment.target: The recommended, forward-looking alternative is the Windows.Web.Http.HttpClient class (or System.Net.Http.HttpClient if you need your code to be portable to other platforms that support .NET).

segment.source: These APIs use System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage to represent an HTTP request.
segment.target: These APIs use System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage to represent an HTTP request.

segment.source: UWP apps do not currently include built-in support for data-intensive scenarios such as line of business (LOB) scenarios.
segment.target: UWP apps do not currently include built-in support for data-intensive scenarios such as line of business (LOB) scenarios.

segment.source: However, you can make use SQLite for local transactional database services.
segment.target: However, you can make use SQLite for local transactional database services.

segment.source: For more info, see SQLite.
segment.target: For more info, see SQLite.

segment.source: Pass absolute URIs, not relative URIs, to Windows Runtime types.
segment.target: Pass absolute URIs, not relative URIs, to Windows Runtime types.

segment.source: See Passing a URI to the Windows Runtime.
segment.target: See Passing a URI to the Windows Runtime.

segment.source: Launchers and Choosers
segment.target: Launchers and Choosers

segment.source: With Launchers and Choosers (found in the Microsoft.Phone.Tasks namespace), a Windows Phone Silverlight app can interact with the operating system to perform common operations such as composing an email, choosing a photo, or sharing certain kinds of data with another app.
segment.target: With Launchers and Choosers (found in the Microsoft.Phone.Tasks namespace), a Windows Phone Silverlight app can interact with the operating system to perform common operations such as composing an email, choosing a photo, or sharing certain kinds of data with another app.

segment.source: Search for Microsoft.Phone.Tasks in the topic Windows Phone Silverlight to Windows 10 namespace and class mappings to find the equivalent UWP type.
segment.target: Search for Microsoft.Phone.Tasks in the topic Windows Phone Silverlight to Windows 10 namespace and class mappings to find the equivalent UWP type.

segment.source: These range from similar mechanisms, called launchers and pickers, to implementing a contract for sharing data between apps.
segment.target: These range from similar mechanisms, called launchers and pickers, to implementing a contract for sharing data between apps.

segment.source: A Windows Phone Silverlight app can be put into a dormant state or even tombstoned when using, for example, the photo Chooser task.
segment.target: A Windows Phone Silverlight app can be put into a dormant state or even tombstoned when using, for example, the photo Chooser task.

segment.source: A UWP app remains active and running while using the FileOpenPicker class.
segment.target: A UWP app remains active and running while using the FileOpenPicker class.

segment.source: Monetization (trial mode and in-app purchases)
segment.target: Monetization (trial mode and in-app purchases)

segment.source: A Windows Phone Silverlight app can use the UWPCurrentApp class for most of its trial mode and in-app purchase functionality, so that code doesn't need to be ported.
segment.target: A Windows Phone Silverlight app can use the UWPCurrentApp class for most of its trial mode and in-app purchase functionality, so that code doesn't need to be ported.

segment.source: But, a Windows Phone Silverlight app calls MarketplaceDetailTask.Show to offer the app for purchase:
segment.target: But, a Windows Phone Silverlight app calls MarketplaceDetailTask.Show to offer the app for purchase:

segment.source: Port that code to call the UWPRequestAppPurchaseAsync method:
segment.target: Port that code to call the UWPRequestAppPurchaseAsync method:

segment.source: If you have code that simulates your app purchase and in-app purchase features for testing purposes, then you can port that to use the CurrentAppSimulator class instead.
segment.target: If you have code that simulates your app purchase and in-app purchase features for testing purposes, then you can port that to use the CurrentAppSimulator class instead.

segment.source: Notifications for tile or toast updates
segment.target: Notifications for tile or toast updates

segment.source: Notifications are an extension of the push notification model for Windows Phone Silverlight apps.
segment.target: Notifications are an extension of the push notification model for Windows Phone Silverlight apps.

segment.source: When you receive a notification from the Windows Push Notification Service (WNS), you can surface the info to the UI with a tile update or with a toast.
segment.target: When you receive a notification from the Windows Push Notification Service (WNS), you can surface the info to the UI with a tile update or with a toast.

segment.source: For porting the UI side of your notification features, see Tiles and toasts.
segment.target: For porting the UI side of your notification features, see Tiles and toasts.

segment.source: For more details on the use of notifications in a UWP app, see Sending toast notifications.
segment.target: For more details on the use of notifications in a UWP app, see Sending toast notifications.

segment.source: For info and tutorials on using tiles, toasts, badges, banners, and notifications in a Windows Runtime app using C++, C#, or Visual Basic, see Working with tiles, badges, and toast notifications.
segment.target: For info and tutorials on using tiles, toasts, badges, banners, and notifications in a Windows Runtime app using C++, C#, or Visual Basic, see Working with tiles, badges, and toast notifications.

segment.source: Storage (file access)
segment.target: Storage (file access)

segment.source: Windows Phone Silverlight code that stores app settings as key-value pairs in isolated storage is easily ported.
segment.target: Windows Phone Silverlight code that stores app settings as key-value pairs in isolated storage is easily ported.

segment.source: Here is a before-and-after example, first the Windows Phone Silverlight version:
segment.target: Here is a before-and-after example, first the Windows Phone Silverlight version:

segment.source: And the UWP equivalent:
segment.target: And the UWP equivalent:

segment.source: Although a subset of the Windows.Storage namespace is available to them, many Windows Phone Silverlight apps perform file i/o with the IsolatedStorageFile class because it has been supported for longer.
segment.target: Although a subset of the Windows.Storage namespace is available to them, many Windows Phone Silverlight apps perform file i/o with the IsolatedStorageFile class because it has been supported for longer.

segment.source: Assuming that IsolatedStorageFile is being used, here's a before-and-after example of writing and reading a file, first the Windows Phone Silverlight version:
segment.target: Assuming that IsolatedStorageFile is being used, here's a before-and-after example of writing and reading a file, first the Windows Phone Silverlight version:

segment.source: And the same functionality using the UWP:
segment.target: And the same functionality using the UWP:

segment.source: A Windows Phone Silverlight app has read-only access to the optional SD card.
segment.target: A Windows Phone Silverlight app has read-only access to the optional SD card.

segment.source: A UWP app has read-write access to the SD card.
segment.target: A UWP app has read-write access to the SD card.

segment.source: For more info, see Access the SD card.
segment.target: For more info, see Access the SD card.

segment.source: For info about accessing photos, music, and video files in a UWP app, see Files and folders in the Music, Pictures, and Videos libraries.
segment.target: For info about accessing photos, music, and video files in a UWP app, see Files and folders in the Music, Pictures, and Videos libraries.

segment.source: For more info, see Files, folders, and libraries.
segment.target: For more info, see Files, folders, and libraries.

segment.target: The next topic is Porting for form factor and UX.
